Arthritis affects the joints of millions of adults in the United States. Supplements may help relieve pain and stiffness in the areas of the body in which arthritis has developed. This article looks at which supplements may be beneficial for people with arthritis. It also explores some of the best supplements and alternative treatments available. All information presented is purely research-based. Arthritis is a general term for conditions that affect joints or areas surrounding the joint. Arthritis can result in [pain](/articles/145750) and stiffness in the affected area of the body. There are approximately [58.5 million](https://www.cdc.gov/arthritis/basics/faqs.htm) The [Arthritis Foundation (AF)](https://www.arthritis.org/health-wellness/treatment/complementary-therapies/supplements-and-vitamins/vitamins-supplements-arthritis) states that some supplements may relieve pain, stiffness, and other symptoms of arthritis. It also suggests using supplements alongside arthritis drugs, not as a substitute. Medications are the only scientifically proven treatment to slow joint damage. A [2020 review](https://www.mdpi.com/2072-6643/12/10/2991) on [rheumatoid arthritis (RA)](/articles/323361) indicates that some supplements may have beneficial effects. However, research into the impact of diet and dietary supplements on RA is limited. Furthermore, the AF highlights the importance of consulting a doctor before taking any supplements for arthritis. Some supplements may interact with other medications or cause side effects. It is also of note that there is little research into the effectiveness of supplements. The [Food and Drug Administration (FDA)](https://www.fda.gov/consumers/consumer-updates/fda-101-dietary-supplements) The FDA also underlines the value of seeking guidance from a doctor about supplements. One of the ways to find quality supplements is to look for a Certificate of Analysis (COA) label. COA labels come from independent third-party companies, such as: [National [ConsumerLab.com](https://www.consumerlab.com/) According to the [NSF](https://www.nsf.org/knowledge-library/what-is-third-party-certification), supplements with a COA label have often undergone testing for: - harmful levels of contaminants - undeclared ingredients - product standardization - accurate ingredient labeling Some supplements have different benefits than others. Fish oil [Fish oil](/articles/319784) contains [omega-3 fatty acids](/articles/325179), which may have anti-inflammatory qualities. It may therefore benefit people with arthritis. Fish oil may also improve heart and eye health, lower [blood pressure](/articles/270644), and promote healthy skin. A [2015 study](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s10753-015-0252-8) on arthritic rats found that fish oil treatments can have positive effects on the joints. However, the authors of a [2016 study](https://ard.bmj.com/content/75/1/23.long) involving 202 people with knee OA or regular [knee pain](/articles/310653) found that there was no additional benefit of taking high dose fish oil over low dose fish oil for participants with knee OA. They also note that further investigation into the efficacy of fish oil is necessary. The [National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases](https://www.niams.nih.gov/health-topics/arthritis#tab-treatment) A person may also have surgery to repair joint damage and help alleviate pain. Alternatively, splints and braces may be useful for people to help reduce movement and prevent pain. There are a variety of supplements that may have anti-inflammatory qualities. This means they may be suitable for people with arthritis and may improve their joint health. A person may wish to consider supplements such as fish oil, collagen, Boswellia, and curcumin. These supplements are available in various forms, including softgels, capsules, powders, and gummies. Supplements are most effective when an individual uses them alongside prescribed medication. However, further research, including larger human trials, into the efficacy of supplements is necessary. A person should consult a doctor before using any supplements, particularly if they are taking any type of medication.
